Students have all evening to log into their class, send an email to their teacher or otherwise engage in the work. This engagement will ensure they are not counted as having been absent.

At the moment, we are sending everyone a reminder call. But we will soon start with targeted calls letting you know if you student was counted as absent.

Thank you so much helping us ensure all students are engaging in their remote work.

We have some NEWS! The Grandview School District is proud to reveal a project that has been many months in the making.

In the spring, before schools closed their doors, our elementary teams had started working on an important and very visible project. Each school was asked to work with an artist to update their mascots and logos. Each school went a different direction with their vision - one school stuck closely with tradition, another chose to update their existing look and another chose a completely new mascot.

As a district, we couldn't be happier with the results!

We want to thank our teams of administrators, teachers, staff and parents who helped shape the look and feel of our new mascots. A lot of thought and effort went into every aspect of these logos, from color selection to exact facial expressions to fonts.

Thank you so much to everyone involved!
#GSDProud #HTProud #McProud #KoalaProud #TogetherGrandviewCan

GHS is having their final technology deployment on Wednesday, August 26 from 3 to 7 p.m. in the GHS Parking lot.

We will be ending our Summer Meal Service on Friday, July 31. Our last meal run will take place on Thursday, July 30.

We want to ensure our families have ample time to make other arrangements.

We also want to thank our community for the support and kind words in regards to the meal service the district has been able to provide since schools closed in mid-March.

We also need to give a special thank you to our food service department, transportation department and the numerous classified staff who jumped in to help when our community needed it the most. Our staff has been serving two meals a day, every weekday to nearly 2,500 students each day starting in mid-March and continuing through the month of July.

We truly are proud to be Grandview School District, and we have shown that together Grandview can make amazing things happen.

#GSDProud #TogetherGrandviewCan

We want to announce an update to our meal service. Beginning on Monday, April 6, we will be going from a three-day-a-week meal delivery schedule back to a five-day-a-week meal delivery schedule. This means we’ll deliver meals every weekday. This will allow us to continue to ensure our students have access to five days of breakfast and lunch. Meal delivery times and locations will remain the same, the only thing changing is the number of days we are physically delivering meals. This also means that left over meals will now be available for pick up by adults every weekday. The times for pick up will remain the same.

For more information go to www.gsd200.org/closure.

In 2020, it's easier than ever. You can respond to the census online at https://my2020census.gov/.

Good evening, everyone. Based on the announcement from Governor Inslee, Grandview School District will be closed to students (including athletics, activities and clubs) from Tuesday, March 17, to Friday, April 24. Monday, March 16, is a normal school day.

We will be taking Tuesday and Wednesday, March 17 and 18, to work on our plans for staff and students during this closure. We will have more information coming during this next week on everything from food service to school work.

As we plan, we are urging our families and community to use the next few days to start coming up with their own contingency plans.

Right now, our main goal is to serve our students and families. We wish we had more for you now. But, rest assured our administrators are working to unpack all of the ramifications, so we ask that you please have patience over the next few days. Thank you to everyone and take care.

Visit www.gsd200.org/covid19resources for up-to-date information from the school district.

Grandview High School hosted a big visitor on Monday afternoon - former Seattle Seahawks left tackle Walter Jones.

The NFL Hall of Famer was in Grandview to help kick off DECA's Entrepreneurship Week. Jones took time to talk to the entire school about his history, how he started playing football and what he decided to do when he left the NFL.

"Take care of your business right now," Jones said.

He talked about having not paid attention to his grades in high school and how he regretted that. Due to his grades, after high school he played football at a junior college. Jones said spending that time at junior college was a great experience for him. It allowed him to get himself together, put school first and continue to grow as a football player.

"I just want to inspire people to do their best no matter what they're doing in life," Jones said.

After playing two years at Florida State, and 13 years in the NFL, Jones left football and started his own clothing line - Best 2 Ever Do it (B2EDi).

Thank you to Walter Jones for coming out and sharing your story!

#GreyhoundProud

With Peachjar we are moving from sending paper flyers home with our scholars...instead families can now expect to get the same flyers emailed directly to their inboxes. Our new e-flyer system - Peachjar - is like a digital backpack, instead of going through your student's actual backpack searching for information, you click a button and everything you need to know will be in one place.

E-flyers will be regularly emailed home, and will also be available on our district website, on each of our school websites and through the Peachjar button on our Grandview School District app.

If you have an email address on file with your child's school, you will receive an introductory email from Peachjar. If you don't have an email address on file, it's easy to add your email address. Go to www.gsd200.org/peachjar for more information on how to update your contact information in our system.

Harkness spoke to the students about how she learned that her grandmother helped more than 300 Jews escape Paris during the German occupation of France, and that her mother had been a courier for the French Resistance during World War II.

Harkness said it wasn't until she started researching her family history that she found out what they had done and been through.

Harkness' visit marks the culmination of the fifth graders studying about the Holocaust.

The theme this year was state symbols. Art teacher Kim Hall said students created everything from a milk carton to an airplane, apples and more.

The students recently traveled to Olympia to see their ornaments on the special tree and had a chance to meet with Washington's First Lady Trudi Inslee.

After the holiday, the student's work will be entered into the state archives and each student will receive a certificate of recognition. #GreyhoundProud

This year Grandview High School's leadership class led the adoption of nine families for the holidays. The students worked with other clubs and organizations to gather food, clothes, gifts, household items and toiletries for the local families - everything they would need to have a nice Christmas.

By Thursday, all of the items going to the adopted families had been organized, wrapped and boxed and were loaded into cars for the trip to the Salvation Army.

Every year the Salvation Army works with the high school to provide names of local families in need.

#GSDProud #GreyhoundProud #AdoptAFamily
